pros: There are tons of opportunity to grow and direct your career at UNC. The benefits are great, the campus is pretty, and it's a family friendly place to work!

pros: I got to meet a lot of new people through this job. Some of my closest friends came from working as a Residential Assistant (RA). I highly recommend if you want to meet new people, and also want to have free housing and dining.
cons: Very stressful. Many of the neighborhood coordinators ((nc) bosses of the RA's) have left, and the school will go through several of these NCs a year. I wouldn't recommend if you prefere seeing a consistency in the staff throughout the year.

review_title: Lots of freedom / IT Leadership needs guideance
pros: if you like managing up. this is the place.
cons: Leadership is forgetful. Makes promises to get you involved then doesn't follow through.

pros: A lot of the faculty here are dedicated teachers who truly care about their students. Their employer tries with its limited resources, to support them.
cons: Like many mid-sized, regional public universities, this one is suffering from declining enrollment and shrinking state support. Therefore, job security in about three years is fragile. Moreover, the administration expects more of its employees than they can humanly deliver, which leads to burnout and high attrition.

pros: Nice people, committed employees, good resources for faculty. Both didactic and clinical options for teaching, remote may be an option for some courses.

Pay is so-so but I'm not sure how much adjuncts make at other places. 
Lots of turnover at higher executive university level in recent years followed by budget cuts and dept reorganizations.

pros: Plenty of study time and work experience were achieved.
cons: Small crummy office and cramped workspace.

job_title: Dining Services Grunt in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Dishroom involves low interaction with cranky customers and encourages comradery with other employees. Freedom of expression encouraged, almost to a fault. Good demographics and low bias toward any sub-group. School breaks are given off, so traveling or going home is easy.
cons: Customers will complain about everything, and then think that as a grunt employee, I can change a bureaucratic government organization for their whim. Morale among employees is low, pay is minimum, and turnover is incredible. I rarely bother learning someone's name until after they have worked there for a month. Some employees are barely function in their assigned roles and should be let go to relieve pressure on those who try to work hard.

review_title: Student work in the library stacks is quiet, slow paced, and has little variation.
pros: Working at the library was part of a student aid loan that reduced what I would have owed in loans.  The work was quiet, but the management allowed for music devices with earplugs as long as the volume was low enough that patrons could be noticed then helped.  Each task varied slightly, but being taught you are close to self reliant in terms of work.  Management is almost always there if you need more instruction or other help.
cons: There is little to no coworker interaction.  Group projects are often in study areas, so talking loudly is not an option.  There is very little variation when it comes to new tasks.  Learning something new is rarely offered.

pros: Great students, staff feels like a community, supervisors interested in professional growth of employees, comfortable size, institution that clearly cares about students.
cons: The University of Northern Colorado is smaller than other universities in its geographical peer group, so it is an open secret that employees can look just down to the road to find a higher salary, and small size means one will likely have to seek another employer in order to move up in career.

pros: Small school, dedicated science faculty, very approachable mentors.  The faculty maintains an "open-door" approach with students.  This isn't a big science/engineering school; however, the team of PhDs working here are very knowledgeable and professional.
cons: Opportunities for lab work are not advertised.  You really have to go out of your way to make it happen.  There are very few ways for undergrad students to gain research experience through the regular curriculum.

review_title: Don't get squeezed - Holmes Dining Hall
job_title: Student Employee -Dish Lead in Greeley, CO
pros:
-Cheap food (2$ a shift meal)
-Access to fresh fruits and vegetables
-Flexible hours
-Small perks
-Internal promotions
-Attentive lower & middle management

The management, despite wanting to squeeze you for every hour of labor you have in your body, will work with your academic schedule. If you don't come back to school, you can't be employed there. Most student supervisors are promoted from within and will have your back when it comes to dealing with senior management or customers being jerks.
cons:
-They could just as easily feed the employees for free
-Only being payed on the 1st and 15th of the month
-Severely unmotivated, deliberately negligent coworkers
-Upper management recommendations run contrary to safety and/or customer satisfaction
- No breaks

Given their payment structure and the mercurial nature of the finance office, you may randomly not be paid. This means you may go as long as 4 weeks without a check. No breaks on shift means that you will be tired, and that if you work there for more than a year, you will probably end up being a burnout employee who will ride the enthusiasm of the new employees as an excuse to not do your job. I only worked there about 4 months and towards the end of it didn't want to be there anymore and held a number of my coworkers in contempt. I should also mention that I sort of got promoted against my will. Moved from regular employee to dish lead which means more responsibilities and having to wrangle cats in a frequently understaffed dishroom at no additional pay.

review_title: Great Place to Work and Develop
pros: Small size allows for professional growth, great student population that wants to grow. Professional staff and faculty are there for the students as well, culture of caring and wanting everyone to succeed.
cons: Greeley isn't the best place for single people. Institution is in the unique and desirable position of having a lot of upper level administrators that have spent their entire careers at the University, can make change a very slow process.

pros:
The best part about being a full-time employee here is you can take 9 credits a year free. You can work with your supervisor on when you can take classes (on your own time). You can therefore earn a degree while working, or just take classes for personal/professional development. 

I also love that you can buy affordable membership to the very good Campus Recreation Center.
cons: The only downside I can think of is your salary and benefits are not negotiable. It is all based on the Colorado legislature each year.

review_title: Great organization that doesn't get enough credit!
pros: Leadership within facilities is terrific! There is a clear and organized plan to maintain and support the University’s infrastructure. Direction is clear and fair and co-workers are great.
cons: The pay in low. It’s a hard choice to weigh the reduced pay with benefits like significant amounts of paid vacations and discounted tuition.

review_title: A positive workplace where you can learn, earn money, and help other college students
pros: If you want to help students from Hawaii, and students who are Asian American or Pacific Islander, this is the best place on campus.
cons: There could be more support from the university.  Like a lot of campus offices, there's lots of turnover, both with student staff and professional staff.

review_title: Great place to learn and grow, especially as a younger professional
pros: Lots of autonomy within my area and students are fantastic. You get to learn a lot about how an organization functions.
cons: Lots of bureaucracy as with any public university, some teachers are great, others are  pretty dreadful. Pay isn't very good compared to other universities. Greeley area isn't particularly nice.

pros: Flexible work, good benefits, noble mission of education, great people to work with, student involvement, 401k matching is the best
cons: Not fully connected with their mission, lack of direction, misallocated budget, priorities seem to be off balance with objectives of improving quality and the student experience

pros: I worked in a variety of work study positions at UNC. They were very flexible with students and the supervisors were very helpful.
cons: The only downside I faced when working at UNC was that I felt micromanaged. Other than that I had a great experience.

review_title: Really Enjoyed My Experience - Would Recommend!
pros: I had WONDERFUL hall directors and leaders to help me. As a result, they taught me a lot and I had wonderful experiences!
cons: It can be difficult working with students, at times they can be accusatory and difficult to manage.

pros: Small campus community feels like family.  Great opportunities for entry level professionals.  Tuition waivers for spouses and dependents.
cons: Pay is low to comparable jobs at other local universities.  Talented professionals leave to fill roles at other Universities for more pay and less responsibility.

pros:
